channel.title: The America Magazine Podcast
channel.description: Weekly interviews with the editors and writers of America magazine, the national Catholic weekly. Hosted by Online Editor Tim Reidy. For a full archive of podcasts, visit americamagazine.org/podcast.
channel.copyright: Copyright © 2012 America Press, Inc. All rights reserved.
channel.itunes:summary: Interviews with editors and writers of America magazine, the national Catholic weekly. Hosted by Online Editor Tim Reidy.
channel.itunes:author: America Press, Inc.

item.title: An Irish Reckoning — August 18-25, 2014 Podcast
item.dc:creator: americamagazine
item.description: A discussion of John Michael McDonagh’s new film “Calvary” with Kerry Weber, Ronan McCoy and Allison Shapiro.  Spoilers included.

item.title: Healing Korea’s ‘Comfort Women’ — August 4-11, 2014 Podcast
item.dc:creator: americamagazine
item.description: Dennis P. Halpin talks about the tragedy of Korea’s “comfort women” and how Pope Francis might reach out to them during his visit to South Korea. You can read Mr. Halpin’s article “Healing an Old Wound” in the August 4-11, 2014 issue of America.
item.content:encoded: Dennis P. Halpin talks about the tragedy of Korea’s “comfort women” and how Pope Francis might reach out to them during his visit to South Korea. You can read Mr. Halpin’s article “Healing an Old Wound” in the August 4-11, 2014 issue of America.

item.title: Mark Uninterrupted — June 23-30, 2014 Podcast
item.dc:creator: americamagazine
item.description: George Drance, S.J., talks about his solo theatrical performance of the entire Gospel of Mark, now playing in New York City through June 15. For more information and tickets visit www.lamama.org.

item.title: The Church in Vietnam — June 9-16, 2014 Podcast
item.dc:creator: americamagazine
item.description: Peter Schineller, S.J., reports on a recent trip to Vietnam, where he taught theology to Jesuit seminarians. Vietnam is home to a large number of religious vocations despite the official atheist position of the Communist government.
item.content:encoded: Peter Schineller, S.J., reports on a recent trip to Vietnam, where he taught theology to Jesuit seminarians. Vietnam is home to a large number of religious vocations despite the official atheist position of the Communist government.

item.title: A Catholic Look at ‘Mad Men’ Season 7
item.dc:creator: americamagazine
item.description: James Martin, S.J., and Tim Reidy discuss the highlights of the first half of the final season of “Mad Men.” Is redemption possible for Don and his coworkers at Sterling Cooper? How are the characters affected by the sins they commit? And what exactly did Don experience in the final moments of the show?
item.content:encoded: James Martin, S.J., and Tim Reidy discuss the highlights of the first half of the final season of “Mad Men.” Is redemption possible for Don and his coworkers at Sterling Cooper? How are the characters affected by the sins they commit? And what exactly did Don experience in the final moments of the show?

media:content.media:title: A Catholic Look at ‘Mad Men’ Season 7

item.title: Singing “The Word’ — May 26-June 2, 2014 Podcast
item.dc:creator: americamagazine
item.description: Roc O’Connor, S.J., talks about the use of Scripture in contemporary liturgical music and how the liturgy can help with the ongoing faith formation of Catholic Christians. Father O’Connor’s article, “We Praise You, O God!,” appears in the May 26-June 2, 2014 issue of America.
item.content:encoded: Roc O’Connor, S.J., talks about the use of Scripture in contemporary liturgical music and how the liturgy can help with the ongoing faith formation of Catholic Christians. Father O’Connor’s article, “We Praise You, O God!,” appears in the May 26-June 2, 2014 issue of America.

item.title: Writing ‘The Word’ — May 19, 2014 Podcast
item.dc:creator: americamagazine
item.description: John W. Martens talks about his new collection of online commentary on the Gospel of Mark and what it is like writing the weekly “Word” column for America. Martens is an associate professor of theology at the University of St. Thomas, St. Paul, Minn. You can follow him @BibleJunkies and read his online commentary at www.biblejunkies.com and at “The Good Word.”
item.content:encoded: John W. Martens talks about his new collection of online commentary on the Gospel of Mark and what it is like writing the weekly “Word” column for America. You can follow him @BibleJunkies and read his online commentary at www.biblejunkies.com and at “The Good Word.”

item.description: Anthony Andreassi, C.O., discusses his new history of Regis High School in New York City, the only tuition-free Jesuit school in the country. Teach Me to Be Generous is published by Fordham University Press.

item.title: A Musical Tribute to Popes John XXIII and John Paul II
item.dc:creator: americamagazine
item.description: Sir Gilbert Levine, known as “the pope’s maestro” for his concerts for Pope John Paul II, talks about a musical celebration on May 5 celebrating the legacy of Saint John XXIII and Saint John Paul II. Learn more about the concert, “Peace through Music ‘In Our Age,’” and its broadcast on PBS stations here.
item.content:encoded: Sir Gilbert Levine, known as “the pope’s maestro” for his concerts for Pope John Paul II, talks about a musical celebration on May 5 celebrating the legacy of Saint John XXIII and Saint John Paul II. item.title: A Trip through Art and History — April 21, 2014 Podcast
item.dc:creator: americamagazine
item.description: Karen Sue Smith, former editorial director of America, introduces listeners to a few notable art exhibits in New York that illuminate crucial turning points in history. They include  “Anders Zorn: Sweden’s Master Painter” at the National Academy, “Italian Futurism, 1909-1944, Reconstructing the Universe” at the Guggenheim and  “Degenerate Art: The Attack on Modern Art in Nazi Germany, 1937″ at the Neue Gallery.
item.content:encoded: Karen Sue Smith, former editorial director of America, introduces listeners to a few notable art exhibits in New York that illuminate crucial turning points in history. They include  “Anders Zorn: Sweden’s Master Painter” at the National Academy, “Italian Futurism, 1909-1944, Reconstructing the Universe” at the Guggenheim and  “Degenerate Art: The Attack on Modern Art in Nazi Germany, 1937″ at the Neue Gallery.
item.itunes:subtitle: Karen Sue Smith, former editorial director of America, introduces listeners to a few notable art exhibits in New York that illuminate crucial turning points in ...
item.itunes:summary: Karen Sue Smith, former editorial director of America, introduces listeners to a few notable art exhibits in New York that illuminate crucial turning points in history. They include "Anders Zorn: Sweden's Master Painter" at the National Academy, "Italian Futurism, 1909-1944, Reconstructing the Universe" at the Guggenheim and "Degenerate Art: The Attack on Modern Art in Nazi Germany, 1937" at the Neue Gallery.
item.itunes:author: America Press, Inc.

media:content.media:title: A Trip through Art and History — April 21, 2014 Podcast

item.title: An Invitation from ‘America’ — April 14, 2014 Podcast
item.dc:creator: americamagazine
item.description: “America is a Catholic ministry, and both of those words—Catholic and ministry—are carefully chosen,” writes editor Matt Malone, S.J., in his recent letter to readers. “Our Jesuit charism guides all of our work. Each time you read America–whether in print or online–you engage with a smart Catholic take on faith and culture, a unique forum for thinking Catholics and those who need to know what Catholics are thinking.” Here Dan Pawlus, VP for advancement, talks more about America’s ministry and how our readers and listeners can play an important role in our growing community.
item.content:encoded: “America is a Catholic ministry, and both of those words—Catholic and ministry—are carefully chosen,” writes editor Matt Malone, S.J., in his recent letter to readers. “Our Jesuit charism guides all of our work. Each time you read America–whether in print or online–you engage with a smart Catholic take on faith and culture, a unique forum for thinking Catholics and those who need to know what Catholics are thinking.” Here Dan Pawlus, VP for advancement, talks more about America’s ministry and how our readers and listeners can play an important role in our growing community.
item.itunes:subtitle: "America is a Catholic ministry, and both of those words—Catholic and ministry—are carefully chosen," writes editor Matt Malone, S.J., in his recent letter to readers. "Our Jesuit ...
item.itunes:summary: "America is a Catholic ministry, and both of those words—Catholic and ministry—are carefully chosen," writes editor Matt Malone, S.J., in his recent letter to readers. "Our Jesuit charism guides all of our work. Each time you read America–whether in print or online–you engage with a smart Catholic take on faith and culture, a unique forum for thinking Catholics and those who need to know what Catholics are thinking." Here Dan Pawlus, VP for advancement, talks more about America's ministry and how our readers and listeners can play an important role in our growing community.
item.itunes:author: America Press, Inc.

item.title: Ecology and War — April 7, 2014 Podcast
item.dc:creator: americamagazine
item.description: This week’s podcast was recorded at the Los Angeles Religious Education Congress in California. We spoke with Sr. Dianne Bergant, who is a Sister of St. Agnes, and the Distinguished Professor of Biblical Studies at Catholic Theological Union in Chicago. She has also served as the President of the Catholic Biblical Association of America and has been an active member of the Chicago Catholic-Jewish Scholars Dialogue for the past 30 years. America readers may recognize her as a former columnist for The Word, which she authored from 2002-2005. At LA Congress, Sr. Dianne spoke about just war theory and the natural world. She argues that while the traditional understanding of “just war” addresses the effect of war on human beings and property, it does not adequately take into account the destruction done to the environment. She spoke with us about the legitimacy of this tradition today.
item.content:encoded: This week’s podcast was recorded at the Los Angeles Religious Education Congress in California. We spoke with Sr. Dianne Bergant, who is a Sister of St. Agnes, and the Distinguished Professor of Biblical Studies at Catholic Theological Union in Chicago. She has also served as the President of the Catholic Biblical Association of America and has been an active member of the Chicago Catholic-Jewish Scholars Dialogue for the past 30 years. America readers may recognize her as a former columnist for The Word, which she authored from 2002-2005. At LA Congress, Sr. Dianne spoke about just war theory and the natural world. She argues that while the traditional understanding of “just war” addresses the effect of war on human beings and property, it does not adequately take into account the destruction done to the environment. She spoke with us about the legitimacy of this tradition today.

item.itunes:summary: This week’s podcast was recorded at the Los Angeles Religious Education Congress in California. We spoke with Sr. Dianne Bergant, who is a Sister of St. Agnes, and the Distinguished Professor of Biblical Studies at Catholic Theological Union in Chicago. She has also served as the President of the Catholic Biblical Association of America and has been an active member of the Chicago Catholic-Jewish Scholars Dialogue for the past 30 years. America readers may recognize her as a former columnist for The Word, which she authored from 2002-2005. At LA Congress, Sr. Dianne spoke about just war theory and the natural world. She argues that while the traditional understanding of “just war” addresses the effect of war on human beings and property, it does not adequately take into account the destruction done to the environment. She spoke with us about the legitimacy of this tradition today.
item.itunes:author: America Press, Inc.

item.title: Catholic and Lakota — March 31, 2014 Podcast
item.dc:creator: americamagazine
item.description: Clementine Bordeaux is an academic coordinator and lecturer in American Indian Studies at the University of California, Los Angeles. An enrolled member of the Rosebud Sioux Tribe, Clementine grew up on the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation in South Dakota, attended the Jesuit-sponsored Red Cloud Indian School, and later worked as youth ministry coordinator in Pine Ridge. In this podcast, Clementine describes her integration of Catholic and Lakota spirituality, her experience of attending the canonization of St. Kateri Tekawitha, and some of the challenges of Native students today.
item.content:encoded: Clementine Bordeaux is an academic coordinator and lecturer in American Indian Studies at the University of California, Los Angeles. An enrolled member of the Rosebud Sioux Tribe, Clementine grew up on the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation in South Dakota, attended the Jesuit-sponsored Red Cloud Indian School, and later worked as youth ministry coordinator in Pine Ridge. In this podcast, Clementine describes her integration of Catholic and Lakota spirituality, her experience of attending the canonization of St. Kateri Tekawitha, and some of the challenges of Native students today.

In this podcast, Clementine describes her integration of Catholic and Lakota spirituality, her experience of attending the canonization of St. Kateri Tekawitha, and some of the challenges of Native students today.

item.title: Ireland and the Angelus — March 24, 2014 Podcast
item.dc:creator: americamagazine
item.description: Rhona Tarrant, a freelance broadcaster for Ireland’s RTE, talks about the tradition of airing the Angelus on Irish television and how it has changed.
item.content:encoded: Rhona Tarrant, a freelance broadcaster for Ireland’s RTE, talks about the tradition of airing the Angelus on Irish television and how it has changed.

item.title: On a Journey with Jesus — March 17, 2014 Issue Now Online
item.dc:creator: americamagazine
item.description: James Martin, S.J., talks about Jesus: A Pilgrimage, a new book that takes readers on a journey with the Jesus of history and the Christ of faith. Father Martin is an editor at large at America and the author of The Jesuit Guide to (Almost) Everything and Between Heaven and Mirth, among other books.

item.title: Report from Gaza — March 10, 2014 Podcast
item.dc:creator: americamagazine
item.description: Matthew McGarry is the Country Representative for Catholic Relief Services in Jerusalem, West Bank and Gaza, a position he had held since July 2012. He is responsible for overseeing approximately 60 staff members in four offices, as well as a range of programming including Humanitarian Assistance, Civil Society, Peacebuilding, Advocacy, and Youth Development—all aimed at serving vulnerable Palestinians. McGarry also has worked with CRS programs in Zimbabwe, Sudan, Pakistan, and Afghanistan.
item.content:encoded: Matthew McGarry is the Country Representative for Catholic Relief Services in Jerusalem, West Bank and Gaza, a position he had held since July 2012. He is responsible for overseeing approximately 60 staff members in four offices, as well as a range of programming including Humanitarian Assistance, Civil Society, Peacebuilding, Advocacy, and Youth Development—all aimed at serving vulnerable Palestinians. McGarry also has worked with CRS programs in Zimbabwe, Sudan, Pakistan, and Afghanistan.

item.title: Animal Ethics — March 3, 2014 Podcast
item.dc:creator: americamagazine
item.description: Charles Camosy talks about his book For Love of Animals: Christian Ethics, Consistent Action, which examines the Christian’s responsibility to “non-human animals” and the ethics of eating meat. Camosy talks what the Christian tradition says about the treatment of animals and the ways in which industrial practices place barriers between consumers and the food on our table.
item.content:encoded: Charles Camosy talks about his book For Love of Animals: Christian Ethics, Consistent Action, which examines the Christian’s responsibility to “non-human animals” and the ethics of eating meat.
